verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: The gate of the inner court facing east must remain shut during the six workdays. But on the Sabbath day and on the day of the new moon, it shall be opened.
verses.comment: The opening of the eastern gate on the Sabbath and new moon links to the rhythm of worship and rest established by God (see Num. 28:9-10). This foreshadows the meaning of sacred time, set apart for worship, echoing the weekly Sabbath and special feast days fulfilled in the new covenant.

verses.text: The prince shall enter through the portico of the gateway from outside and stand by the post of the gateway. The priests will prepare his burnt offering and his peace offerings, and he shall worship at the threshold of the gate and then go out. The gate will not be shut until evening.
verses.comment: The role of the prince and the priests shows the distinction between leadership and ministerial priesthood. The prince's unique access indicates a role of mediation, reminding us of Christ as the ultimate High Priest and King.

verses.text: The people of the land shall also worship at the entrance of that gate before the LORD on Sabbaths and new moons.
verses.comment: All the people are called to worship on designated days. This inclusion of the whole community in worship highlights the value of communal liturgy, pointing to the importance of unified worship in the Church.

verses.text: The burnt offering the prince shall bring to the LORD on the Sabbath day shall be six male lambs without blemish and a ram without blemish.
verses.comment: The requirement for unblemished animals for sacrifice points towards the sinlessness of Christ, the perfect Lamb of God. These offerings foreshadow Christ’s ultimate sacrifice.

verses.text: And the grain offering shall be one ephah with the ram, and with the lambs as much as he is able to give, and a hin of oil with each ephah.
verses.comment: The mention of grain and oil offerings alongside animal sacrifice illustrates the fullness of worship, involving gifts from both flock and field, hinting toward offering all of one’s life to God.

verses.text: And on the day of the new moon, he shall offer a young bull without blemish, six male lambs, and a ram—they shall be without blemish.
verses.comment: The new moon sacrifice shows extra solemnity, indicating cycles of renewal and the importance of consecrating time. These sacrifices remind us of the new beginnings given to us in Christ.

verses.text: With the bull he shall offer an ephah and with each ram an ephah for a grain offering, and as much as he is able with the lambs, and a hin of oil with each ephah.
verses.comment: The offering proportions show generosity in worship. The prince’s freedom to give extra with the lambs signifies the importance of giving to God without legalistic limits.

verses.text: When the prince enters, he shall come in by way of the porch of the gate, and go out by the same way.
verses.comment: The prince’s particular entrance and exit signify order and reverence in liturgical worship, echoing the enduring role of sacred leadership.

verses.text: When the people of the land come before the LORD at the appointed feasts, whoever enters by the north gate to worship must go out by the south gate, and whoever enters by the south gate must go out by the north gate. No one shall return by the way of the gate by which he entered, but each shall go out straight ahead.
verses.comment: The prescribed pattern for entering and exiting emphasizes reverence, order, and unity, hints at the transformation and renewal that genuine worship brings about—a theme fulfilled spiritually in Christian liturgy.

verses.text: The prince shall be in the midst of them. When they come in, he shall come in, and when they go out, he shall go out.
verses.comment: The prince present among the people hints at God dwelling with his people. This prefigures Christ, who is both King and Priest, present with his Church (see Matt. 28:20).

verses.text: At the feasts and the appointed festivals, the grain offering with a young bull shall be an ephah; with a ram, an ephah; and with the lambs, as much as he is able, and with each ephah a hin of oil.
verses.comment: These instructions reiterate the blend of structure and freedom in God’s worship. Worship requires both obedience and the offering of one’s heart.

verses.text: When the prince prepares a freewill burnt offering or peace offerings as a freewill offering to the LORD, the gate facing east shall be opened for him, and he shall offer his burnt offering and his peace offerings as he does on the Sabbath day. Then he shall go out, and after he goes out, the gate will be shut.
verses.comment: The freewill offerings by the prince through the eastern gate highlight the inviting mercy and openness of God. The link to the Sabbath further draws spiritual connection to rest and grace.

verses.text: You must provide a year-old male lamb without blemish as a daily burnt offering to the LORD; you must provide it every morning.
verses.comment: The daily sacrifice points to the ongoing need for atonement and continual worship. Christians see this fulfilled in the perpetual memorial established by Christ in the new and everlasting covenant.

verses.text: You shall also provide a grain offering with it morning by morning, a sixth of an ephah with a third of a hin of oil, to moisten the fine flour—a grain offering to the LORD; this is a perpetual ordinance.
verses.comment: The daily grain offering emphasizes the unending call to consecrate one’s daily life to God. The idea of a perpetual ordinance foreshadows the ongoing, unbroken worship of God’s people.

verses.text: Thus they shall provide the lamb, the grain offering, and the oil, morning by morning, as a regular burnt offering.
verses.comment: Regular daily offerings signal a rhythm of worship and devotion, paralleling early Christian devotion to daily prayer and the remembrance of Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: If the prince gives a gift out of his inheritance to any of his sons, it is to belong to his sons; it is their possession by inheritance.
verses.comment: The inheritance given by the prince to his sons echoes the lasting promises and the fatherly provision that God grants his faithful people.

verses.text: But if he gives a gift from his inheritance to one of his servants, it will be his until the year of freedom; then it shall return to the prince. Only his inheritance may go to his sons.
verses.comment: This rule protects the inheritance as a perpetual family possession. Spiritually, it points to the secure eternal inheritance of the children of God.

verses.text: The prince must not take any of the people's inheritance by oppression, thrusting them out of their property; he must give his sons inheritance from his own property, so that none of my people will be separated from his property.'
verses.comment: Justice and protection of personal inheritance show God’s care for the just treatment of his people and prefigure his righteous Kingship.

verses.text: Then he brought me through the entrance, which was at the side of the gate, to the holy chambers for the priests, which faced north. And there was a place at the far west end.
verses.comment: The holy chambers for the priests highlight the sanctity of the priesthood and the distinction of holy service, foreshadowing the spiritual priesthood of all believers.

verses.text: He said to me, 'This is the place where the priests shall boil the guilt offering and the sin offering, and where they shall bake the grain offering, so that they do not have to bring them out into the outer court and so transmit holiness to the people.'
verses.comment: Sacrifice preparation within holy grounds shows that holiness is something received rather than presumed, echoing the set-apartness required for approaching God.

verses.text: Then he brought me out to the outer court and led me to the four corners of the court; in each corner of the court there was an enclosed court.
verses.comment: The four corner courts emphasize the completeness and orderliness of God's temple, reminding us of the universal call of the Church.

verses.text: In the four corners of the court were enclosed courts, forty cubits long and thirty wide; all four corners had the same dimensions.
verses.comment: The symmetry and measured perfection of the courts hint toward the order and unity that God desires for his holy people.

verses.text: There was a row of masonry around in them, around the four, and boiling places were made under the rows round about.
verses.comment: Provisions for cooking the sacrifices show the practical side of temple worship, which was both spiritual and material. The care for details is a model for reverence in worship.

verses.text: Then he said to me, 'These are the places where those who serve the temple shall boil the sacrifices of the people.'
verses.comment: The temple servants preparing sacrifices for the people highlights the mediation necessary for worship and anticipates the ministry of ordained ministers within the New Covenant. This continuity points to the perpetual pattern of God establishing sacred servants for holy offerings.
